title: Foundation English for University Studies

description: This course aims to lay the comprehensive English language foundation needed for university studies by engaging students in multi-modal learning activities. title: Speaking and Presenting like TED
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
description: The course aims to inspire students to speak and present more like TED. The course adopts a learning-by-doing approach: students are expected to come to class prepared to share their critical analyses of TED talks and present ideas in their respective academic discipline. title: English Through Literary Analysis
requirements: Prerequisite: ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
description: In this course, students of the Faculty of Arts will read different texts such as short stories, novellas and parts of novels and explore other forms of media (such as visual art, film and television). These serve as means for students to learn about some well-established critical approaches in literary theory and engage actively in discussion regarding the content and ideas in the texts, as well as the writing strategies used by the authors. These concepts in literature are universal throughout the Humanities and it is hoped that through this course, students will develop their critical thinking skills via textual analyses and that these skills can be transferred to their own disciplines. The texts and film adaptations cover different genres, cultural backgrounds and eras with topics that will focus on social change. These texts and adaptations will be used to highlight different critical literary approaches used in analyses of literature and film. Students are expected to apply these ‘lenses’ to their own writing and to critically evaluate their work and the work of their classmates. Participation in class discussions of the assigned readings is crucial – which means reading or viewing the texts in preparation for each class is essential.
outcome: By the end of this course students will be able to: Analyze a literary text using different critical theories;   Compose an original, logical and well-reasoned academic paper in the form of a literary analysis essay;   Deliver an analytical presentation/discussion based on their literary analysis essay; and   Undertake in-depth analysis and evaluation/critique of their own written work and the work of their classmates.
syllabus: Learning topics include: Feminist Literary Theory  Students learn how characters, especially the female characters, are portrayed and how the portrayal of female characters reinforces or undermines sexual stereotypes.   Marxist Literary Theory Students learn the role of class (social and economic standing) and ideology (main underlying principles) in literature as they reflect, promote, and sometimes challenge the prevailing social order. They will focus on how those in power seek to maintain that power, in part by justifying it through art and literature. They will also focus on the struggle that exists between the working class and the ruling (elite) class.   Postcolonial Literary Theory Students learn to read for an awareness of representation of non-Europeans as exotic or ‘Other’ in literature. They also learn to focus on language to see if the colonizer's language is permanently tainted, to write in it involves acquiescence in colonial structures. Other topics include observing the identity as doubled or unstable (identify with colonizer and colonized) in literature, and also learn to be aware of cross-cultural interactions within literary work.These topics are transferrable to various disciplines in the Faculty of Arts. These concepts are also universal in understanding the trends in humanities. Understanding them will help students develop their critical thinking and develop their use of the English language in critiquing, discussing and analyzing film and literature.

title: English for Education Students I

description: This course is designed for second-year students in the Faculty of Education to improve their powers of persuasion through spoken and written academic English. title: English for Law Students
description: The course aims to ease students into legal studies by teaching students language skills to help them succeed in their legal studies. Specifically, students will be introduced to the Answer to Problem Question – a basic genre that all law students must master in order for them to demonstrate their legal knowledge and competence in their studies. They will learn to present this genre in two modalities: a written answer, and a presentation.Advisory: For Year 1 students of the Faculty of Law only.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to:1. write an Answer to Problem Question by using appropriatea) structureb) formalityc) legal terms2. deliver the answer in a presentation by using appropriatea) verbal communication strategiesb) non-verbal communication strategiesc) plain language
syllabus: The course focuses on the Answer to Problem Question, an important genre for all law students. By focusing on the structure and language of this genre, students can be better prepared to tackle problem questions in their law classes.The course begins by teaching students professional presentation skills, focusing on verbal and non-verbal communication strategies, so as to prepare students to effectively communicate with their future colleagues and clients.Then students are taught how to solve a Problem Question by using the IRAC model (issue, reason, application, conclusion). They are also taught the specific method and language features of writing an Answer to the Problem Question.Then students learn to apply the taught presentation skills to present their Answer to Problem Question, using plain English to communicate their across persuasively.

title: English for Chinese Medicine Students
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
description: This course aims to prepare second-year students in the School of Chinese Medicine for the language demands within a range of health-care contexts where Chinese Medicine practice is applied. Learning topics include use of lay language, writing and presentation for the general public. Coursework and/or learning activities focus on the language use in achieving different genres: 1) role play demonstrating students’ use of lay language in explaining Chinese Medicine diagnosis and treatments to patients during consultation; 2) educational pamphlet and feature article about Chinese Medicine concepts or issues for the general public; 3) presentation about daily application of Chinese Medicine concepts to the general public; and 4) discussion about some controversial Chinese Medicine application. title: English for Engineering Students I – Extensive Reading about Contemporary Issues

description: This course is designed to increase student literacy of contemporary issues, especially in subjects related to business, science, and technology. Students learn about these topics directly through assigned readings and discussions, but emphasis is also placed on life-long learning by allowing students to select their own topics to read and teaching them skills to critical evaluate information sources. Learning topics also include reading strategies, expository writing skills, and presentation skills. Coursework includes reflective writing on assigned readings, summary report writing, the ethical use of AI Chatbots, presentation tasks, and independent learning activities. outcome: By the end of this course, students will be able to:1. make critical judgments about information sources; 2. implement reading strategies to select and understand news articles; 3. identify independent learning activities to develop lifelong learning; 4. write a documented summary report exploring multiple sides of an issue; 5. create proper in-text citations & reference list using APA 7th; 6. write a one paragraph article summarizing the authors main ideas; 7. ethically utilize AI Chatbots to help critically assess articles and improve their writing; 8. give informative presentations on current issues relating to business, science, and technology using appropriate language and structure; 9. develop their presentation delivery & visual aid skills; 10. give a self-evaluation on their presentations; and 11. evaluate and provide constructive feedback on peer presentations.

description: This course introduces students to a variety of medical practices from across the world. The course consists of 5 modules: an introductory module and 4 other modules covering the medical traditions of a particular culture or region. Learning materials encompass a range of written texts, including book chapters, websites, journal articles, and government reports, as well as listening resources from YouTube and TED Talks. Through these materials, students have the opportunity to learn about how different cultures approach the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of illnesses. In addition, students will also develop an understanding of socio-political aspects related to traditional medicine, such as health policy and education. title: Essentials of Public Speaking
requirements:

description: This course aims to help students become more effective and confident public speakers. Learning topics include vocal variation, diction, rhetoric, formality and delivery. Throughout the course students will learn to conduct critical analyses of exemplary speeches and be given opportunities to write, rehearse, and perform informal and formal speeches using techniques they have acquired. This course is particularly suitable for students who have already attained some basic presentation skills and want to further improve their spoken English.
outcome: By the end of this course, students will be able to:  1) analyse the language and rhetoric of sample speeches, so as to appreciate the content and delivery employed by the speakers; 2) understand the importance of rhetoric in speeches; 3) apply Cicero’s five rhetorical stages: invention, disposition, style, memory and delivery; and 4) write and deliver formal and informal speeches effectively.
syllabus: Learning topics include:  1) Using your voice (articulation, pitch, pace and volume) effectively 2) Understanding and practicing the art of storytelling 3) Analysing the differences between presentations and speeches 4) Analysing the differences between formal and informal speeches 5) Analysing sample speeches 6) Understanding rhetoric  7) Applying different rhetorical devices to create impact 8) Planning the right structure of own speech 9) Writing scripts with style, substance and clarity

title: Intercultural Communication Through English
requirements: Pre-requisites: ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses AND ELTU2004 or 2005 or 2006 or 2011 or 2013 or 2014 or 2016 or 2017 or 2018 or 2019 or 2020 or 2022 or 2023 or 2024 or 2026 or 2406 or 2412 or exemption from these courses
description: Developing intercultural competencies is a lifelong process. This course aims to enhance students’ intercultural communication skills in English, while fostering global citizenship. Throughout the course, students are guided to develop the attitudes, skills, and knowledge which can facilitate meaningful intercultural communication. Students will engage in tasks such as reading, watching videos, discussions, and the analysis of intercultural dialogues to help them to become more global-minded interculturally competent speakers of English.The main course objectives are to practice deep listening (i.e., listening for understanding), suspend snap judgments about cultural difference, and increase cultural awareness of self and others. In other words, the course aims to develop some of the core attributes that are expected of CUHK graduates i.e., intercultural understanding and sensitivity, and global-mindedness.
outcome: By the end of this course, students will be able to:1. demonstrate a critical understanding of what meaningful intercultural communication entails;2. demonstrate the ability to recognize and appreciate cultural and linguistic diversity;3. make reasoned verbal and non-verbal choices in intercultural encounters;4. produce coherent, insightful accounts of their intercultural experience in English; and5. reflect on and assess their L2/ cultural self-awareness and intercultural communication skills, and set realistic goals for further enhancement of their English language proficiency, intercultural competence, and global-mindedness.
syllabus: Learning topics include:1. Introduction to language and intercultural communication- understanding language and intercultural communication- identifying the attitudes, skills, and knowledge that facilitate intercultural communication2. Language and non-verbal communication- understanding, discussing, and analyzing the relationship between language, communication, culture, power and context- identifying different types and functions of nonverbal codes- discussing and explaining the influence of culture on non-verbal communication- practicing intercultural communication skills in English3. Language and identity in intercultural communication- identifying multiple characteristics of identity- describing the relationship between language, culture and identity- explaining the role of identity in intercultural communication- reflecting on one’s identity and how it affects one’s language use in context4. Language and intercultural relationships- discussing, identifying, and analyzing factors that affect intercultural relations in different contexts- explaining the potential impact of culture in conflict situations- discussing and presenting strategies for dealing effectively and appropriately with intercultural conflicts- practicing intercultural communication skills in English5. Global citizenship and intercultural competence- identifying the traits and characteristics of global citizens- describing ways to enhance one’s intercultural competence and intercultural/global citizenry- practicing intercultural communication skills in English

title: Postgraduate Presentation Skills
description: This course is designed for postgraduate students who want to upgrade their spoken English and presentation skills for academic purposes. Specifically, it focuses on developing effective communication skills for tutorials, proposals/protocols, seminars, conferences and oral defence. Students will be introduced to key concepts and strategies, such as audience-awareness, the power of summary, vocal advantage, and effective delivery of well-organized content materials using visual aids. Coursework consists of oral presentations and discussion of a wide variety of academic output.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to:  1. develop an ability to plan and organize ideas logically in a formal setting; 2. develop an appreciation of the importance of English presentation skills; 3. build confidence step by step in presenting academic outputs in formal settings; 4. present the gist of a research study, thesis, or statement of purpose concisely; 5. speak with clarity (in lay language) on their chosen area of special interest and adequately answer questions from at the audience; 6. strike a balance between the audience, the speaker, and content; and 7. self-evaluate and give feedback to peers on various presentations.
syllabus: 1) Course Familiarization - Introduction to the course structure  - teaching topics - assessment structure - project requirements - resources  2) Principles and Practice - Skills and strategies in giving presentations  - reflecting on one’s speaking abilities (e.g. pre-course speaking ex.) - developing good habits of better speaking in English - clear articulation and pronunciation practice  3) Honesty in Academic Work - Quoting, paraphrasing, summarizing skills when using secondary resources  - Referencing and giving credit where it is due  4) Seminar Skills - Planning and leading a seminar  - addressing basic requirements of the seminar - answering basic seminar questions and objectives - chairing a seminar - leading and taking part in academic discussions  5) Giving Prepared Speeches - Preparing a formal speech  - Setting goals and objectives - Understanding the audience - Gathering details - Summarizing main ideas - Organizing and presenting them - Delivering the speech - Showing position, problem, possibilities and making a proposal - Developing greater confidence and skills in delivery  6) Giving impromptu speeches - Understanding and meeting basic requirements  - The challenge of thinking on your feet - Giving impromptu talk and not talking impromptu - Practicing and meeting expectations of the audience  7) Final Speech Project in Persuasion - Putting it all together and presenting your case  - Element of persuasion: appeals and logic, evidence / support - Structure of persuasion - Process of developing a persuasive writing strategy - Presenting the problem, method, solution, benefits, proposal

title: Grammar in Context
requirements: Not for students who have taken ELTU1106
description: This course aims to help students acquire conceptual understanding of English grammar with a specific focus on areas that are most problematic for university students. To enhance a conceptual understanding, the course encourages an inductive approach to grammar rules, using a variety of texts for illustration of grammatical features in use. Both spoken and written contexts will be used There will be various language activities, games and exercises to raise students’ awareness of the contextualized use of English grammar. Coursework includes grammar exercises, self-access language learning (SALL) assignments, a mid-term test, a grammar project and a final examination. Advisory: For students who have attained HKDSE English level 3 or 4 or its equivalence.

title: English Through Popular Culture
requirements: Prerequisite(s): ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
description: This course aims to develop language skills and vocabulary through the analysis of stimuli from popular culture. Students will increase their ability to analyze such materials from a cultural and linguistic perspective, and to speak fluently and accurately about them. Additionally, students will develop an awareness of learning strategies for maximizing the potential of such materials in their own independent learning. Coursework includes analysis of songs, films and television shows and strategy development for using popular culture materials in academic and language learning. This 2-unit course is suitable for students from all faculties, and prerequisites are ELTU 1001 or ELTU 1002 or exemption from these courses.

title: English through the Visual Arts
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): ELTU1001 or ELTU1002 or exemption from these courses
description: This course is designed for students who have an interest in visual art and who would like to learn how to talk meaningfully about their personal interest. Along with developing the necessary language tools associated with art, students will be provided with many opportunities to describe, analyse and critique works of art. Coursework is made up of two components: the first component is provided by the teacher, and consists of the basic guidelines and materials necessary for developing this communication skill. The second consists of a teacher-approved programme of learning activities that is to be designed by the students themselves, either individually or in pairs. Advisory: Recommended for Year 2 students of the Faculty of Arts.

title: English Through Creative Writing
description: This course aims to strengthen English language skills by introducing students to Creative Writing. Learning topics include short stories, creative non-fiction, poetry and the revision process. Coursework consists of a Creative Writing portfolio, a short reflective essay and a public reading project. This 2-unit course is an elective for all undergraduate students (except ENGE and ELED students).

title: English Through Film
description: This is an integrated theme-based course designed for students who want to improve their English analytical and discussion skills. Specifically, it will focus on the analysis of linguistic, cultural and intellectual aspects of films. Coursework will include class discussions of assigned films (viewed outside of class), a series of short talks prepared by students on an aspect of film, a written essay and a group presentation. This course is particularly suitable for students who feel confident in their English-language abilities.
